messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> teemu kanstren wrote:
>
> > I guess that definition is in line with the default Adapter classes
> provided
> > in the JDK. I always rather think of an Adapter as a component that
> converts
> > the interface of a component to match the interface of another, as I
> think
> > it is defined in the GoF book. Don't know what does that have to do
> with an
> > empty strategy, or what is an empty strategy though. But I'm sure we
> will
> > soon know :).
>
> If that's what an Adapter is, then what is a Bridge? I don't have my
> copy of Design Patterns handy right now. What you describe is what I
> would call a Bridge.

I don't think so. Unfortunately, whoever borrowed my Design Patterns
sometime last fall has yet to return it, and the person I usually borrow
it from is not around, so I'm thrown on the mercy of Google, which seems
to confirm that teemu is right:

Adapter: convert the interface of one component to match the interface
of another
Bridge: separate an abstraction from its implementation, so they can
evolve independently.

I think that the Request / Runner separation in JUnit 4 is an example of
Bridge: the Request hierarchy for requesting that classes ATest, BTest,
and CTest be run is separate from the Runner hierarchy for enumerating
and running tests. (But I might be wrong--there are qualified members
of the JUnit development team who have corrected my overapplications of
patterns terminology in the past.)

David Saff
